maml:description.maml:para: Adds an IPv6 vendor or user class to the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Add-DhcpServerv6Class cmdlet adds an IPv6 vendor or user class to the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The VendorId parameter needs to be specified if a vendor class is being added, but should not be specified for a user class.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being added.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

Specifies the data for the vendor or user class. This is the actual value expected to be present in the request from the client belonging to this vendor or user class. The format for this parameter can be given as ANSI or hexadecimal.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv6 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description string to be set on the vendor or user class being added.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the enterprise number of the vendor class. If this parameter is specified for user class, then an error is displayed.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv6 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.

Specifies the data for the vendor or user class. This is the actual value expected to be present in the request from the client belonging to this vendor or user class. The format for this parameter can be given as ANSI or hexadecimal.
Specifies the description string to be set on the vendor or user class being added.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being added.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.
Specifies the enterprise number of the vendor class. If this parameter is specified for user class, then an error is displayed.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Type User -Data "LabComputers"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a DHCPv6 user class for lab computers.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "Vendor Class for Printers" -Type Vendor -Data "JetPrinters" -VendorId 100

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a DHCPv6 vendor class for printers from a specific vendor identified by the vendor ID.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the IPv6 vendor or user class from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Get-DhcpServerv6Class cmdlet gets the IPv6 vendor or user class from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
If only the Type parameter is specified, then all of the classes of the specified class type on the DHCP server service are retrieved.
If neither the Name nor the Type parameter is specified, then all of the user and vendor classes on the DHCP server service are retrieved.
If only the Name parameter is specified, then the class for that Name parameter value will be returned.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class which is to be retrieved.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class which is to be retrieved.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets all of the DHCPv6 class definitions, both vendor and user, which are present on the DHCP server service.
This example gets all of the DHCPv6 vendor class definitions which are present on the DHCP server service.
This example gets the DHCPv6 vendor class definition for the vendor class named MSUCClient.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the specified IPv6 vendor class or user class from a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Remove-DhcpServerv6Class cmdlet deletes the specified IPv6 vendor class or user class from a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being deleted.
Specifies the type of the class being deleted. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the name of the vendor or user class being deleted.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class being deleted. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Type User

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes the DHCPv6 user class for lab computers.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Remove-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "Vendor Class for Printers" -Type Vendor

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes the DHCPv6 vendor class defined for printers.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the properties of an IPv6 vendor or user class on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.

The Set-DhcpServerv6Class cmdlet modifies the properties of an IPv6 vendor or user class on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server. At least one of the Description, VendorId, and Data parameter must be specified. The VendorId parameter must not be specified if a user class is being modified.
Specifies the name of vendor or user class being modified.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.

Specifies the data for the specified vendor or user class. This parameter value is expected to be present in the request from the client belonging to the vendor class. The format for this parameter can be given as ANSI or hexadecimal.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description to set on the class being modified.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the enterprise number of the vendor class.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.

Specifies the data for the specified vendor or user class. This parameter value is expected to be present in the request from the client belonging to the vendor class. The format for this parameter can be given as ANSI or hexadecimal.
Specifies the description to set on the class being modified.
Specifies the name of vendor or user class being modified.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of the class. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Vendor or User.
Specifies the enterprise number of the vendor class.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "User Class for Lab Computers" -Data "LabComputers" –Type User

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the data for the DHCPv6 user class for lab computers.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-DhcpServerv6Class -Name "Vendor Class for Printers" -Data "JetPrinters" -VendorId 100 –Type Vendor

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the data and vendor identifier (ID) for the DHCPv6 vendor class for printers.
